Oh thou, orr what remaynes of thee,</br>Rowley, streaming wythe the morning due,</br>Uppone the lethale daie,</br>To Redcliffe took his waie,</br>Wythe antiquarian Barrett for hys guide;</br>Than dydd hys furiouse hande</br>Steale monie deeds of lande,</br>Not even myghty Milles hys guilte can hide.

Into his baskett felle,</br>As ravenous as helle,</br>Thousandes of parchments went:</br>Brystowannes have y tolde,</br>That gests and stories olde,</br>Were written on those parchmentes wondrous quent.

Oh thou, where'er (thie bones att reste)</br>Thye spryte to haunte delyghteth best,</br>Whetherr on Bristowe Bridge, or Redcliffe Churche,</br>Or else 'mongst moth-devoured bookes,</br>In which bold Bryant sometimes lookes,</br>Tho' oft hys learnyge leaves hym in the lurche.

Or should thie spiritt chuse to stopp,</br>In Catcott's warehouse, or hys shopp,</br>And sigh to be amenged the pewter plates;</br>Orr ynne old Canygne's magic roome,</br>Envelopp'd wythe a twilight gloome,</br>Where Glynn, and Smith may wayle their emptie pates.

Orr 'mongst the pots, and bottles pil'd,</br>By busie Barrett staring wild,</br>Guarde alle thie sermons wyth religious care;</br>That Exon's Dean maie never finde</br>A perfect copie to his minde,</br>And print it as a booke of posies rare.</br>
